Comment: KD, it's possible that Trump has never lied. However, almost everything he spouts is untrue.
For example, last year he said that the winery he owns in Virginia is the largest winery on the east coast. That statement is untrue ... by two measures. First, it's not even the largest winery in Virginia. Secondly, he doesn't own the winery (it's a limited liability corporation, and its owners are not a matter of public record).
It's possible he didn't lie about this fact because he wanted it to be true so badly that in his deluded, narcissistic mind he had convinced himself that it actually was true.
In other words, he's more a sicko than a liar, and he's got all the Re-pubics in his cabinet and most of them in Congress kissing his ***, no matter what outrageous comments he blathers.

Comment: You don't appear to be a very apt biologist, but rather a nasty troll spreading ill informed false moral equivalency.  Comparing a few thousand annual dropout sockeye salmon in directed fisheries in Bristol Bay to a large scale mechanized mining operation is just plain stupid.  These mining operations have a terrible track record in Canada, Eastern Europe, China, South America, and New Guinea.  The potential for irrevocable harm to the habitat is very real.  Dead sockeye salmon resulting from gilnetting that go unharvested will contribute to the nutrient cycle.  Moreover it is has been going on since the inception of the most productive commercial wild salmon fishery on earth for nearly 140 years and has not done harm to the sustainability of the run.  Damaging habitat however is the most widespread cause of extirpation of fish stocks.

Comment: Dude, you're essentially reiterating what I just said (like three times already). I know what causes earthquakes, and judging by this conversation probably have a better grasp of it than you. All earthquakes are caused by some sort of unique geology. In the case of Oklahoma the cause is injecting large amounts of waste water into the Arbuckle formation (much larger amounts than what we inject here in Colorado). The Arbuckle has unique characteristics that make it different than the formations we inject water into in Colorado, one being it directly overlies crystalline basement rock. The interface between the Arbuckle and the basement rock is the perfect spot for a fault to slip when lubricated/pressured up. Comment: It’s easy to get caught up in the deeply flawed character of Donald Trump. We also need to recognize the policy catastrophe of this presidency.
This past week Trump ordered an end to the Obama-era executive action that shielded around 800,000 young undocumented immigrants – often called Dreamers – from deportation under what’s been known as the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, or DACA.
Look at other of Trump’s recent policy decisions and you see the same arbitrary and unnecessary cruelty. What’s the point of banning transgender people from military service? Of siding in court with a businessman who doesn’t want to sell his services to gay couples? Of weakening the standard for responding to sexual violence in universities? Of banning Syrian refugees and reducing by half the number of refugees admitted to the United States?
There is no point, in terms of policy. None of these decisions makes America safer or economically stronger or fairer.

Comment: My wife retired as a full-time nursing professor a couple of years ago and her position is now being staffed by several part-timers.  The nursing program has been running since the colleges took them over in the 60's and has no signs of slowing down.  How is this reacting to market forces?  They need experienced full-time staff for the majority of the program delivery and continuity to ensure quality.

The reality is that instead these colleges have loaded up management administrators at the expense of front-line teaching staff.  The number of these managers has DOUBLED over the past 16 years while the number of faculty members has decreased relative to the number of students in the same period.  I estimate that the college system could save $200 million annually just by going back to the 2001 ratio of management to students.

What other organizations have doubled their management staff ratio?  It's ridiculous.

Comment: Wrong. New Hampshire does not, and never did, have a general sales or income tax. Nor can towns levy local sales taxes. NH does have a interest and dividend tax, but it has a high threshold and exemptions.

While we don't have a statewide sales or income tax, most pay property taxes, either directly, or through rents. And many of us pay a sales tax, particularly in smaller communities. So it's not a free ride.

Yep, we get a welfare check every year, but that is likely to end when the stark fiscal enormity of what Alaska faces finally sinks in. So spend it wisely. But it does not, and never has, come "compliments of the oil companies". It's OUR oil, and we are selling it to the oil companies, albeit at fire-sale rates. But that's another story. If the oil companies were giving us "complimentary" cash, other than the pittance that they drip to charities for "goodwill", they would be rightly sued by their stockholders.

Lawmakers doing likewise should get the boot. Stupid, stupid us.

Comment: I see this assertion a lot, but have never read why some people believe it to be indisputable truth.  It is not.

"As humans, we also need rituals"

SOME people may DESIRE to particiopate in rituals, but to say that ALL people "need" rituals is not true.  

In the context of religion, some desire some rituals in certain contexts (they don't "need" ritual), others pretty much forgo ritual (for example, Quakers).  

In the early church, the eucharist was a meal, presided over by someone chosen from the congregation, or by the head of household, who might have been either a man or a woman. No priests.

The rituals that have developed during the history of the RCC and christianity in general,  were developed by men, and sometimes have become a bit ludicrous. When any small change from the GIRM becomes a matter for civil war in the RCC, the notion of  the importance of 'ritual" has gone too far, becoming an end in itself that is often even at odds with true prayer and true spirituality.

Comment: You and jsaturn are missing the bigger points to this.

1) Washington, Jefferson, etc. were slave holders, and that is wrong. However, we are talking about honoring people that felt the need to rebel against the US government in order to uphold an institution that a majority of the nation at the time thought had run its course. Most of the western world at this point had already ended slavery in their colonies.

2) 90,000 Kentuckians fought for the Union, while 35,000 fought for the CSA, and yet, in that state, there are 72 Confederate monuments to only 2 Union ones. In other words, that state CHOSE to honor a side of which it was not on during the Civil War (Kentucky never left the Union) in the years that followed. Maryland is in the same boat.....a non-seceding slave state that has chosen to do more to honor the Confederacy, despite the fact that more Marylanders fought for the Union.

Perhaps you should be asking yourself why these states CHOSE to honor that side over the years.

Comment: I agree with Ms. Nagata's overall critique of cultural appropriation and the damaging effects it can have. While a product of cultural appropriation (a movie, a book, an inauthentic lūʻau performance) might be harmless in itself, for those whom they offend, they are felt to reenact and perpetuate the injustices of history. 

However, I depart from her view when she suggests that storytelling is necessarily a form of appropriation. Does one need to be Jewish to make a movie about the Holocaust? Does one need to be indigenous to make a film about indigenous people (I think the brilliant recent film, "Embrace of the Serpent" answers that question with a resounding no). The filmmakers have taken creative license with the source material, and some are likely find this offensive, but that does not mean a culture has been stolen or appropriated. 

Now, the money that Disney is going to make from the film is another matter, and one certainly worth the debate.

Comment: BRick sets overtime and adapts itself to the moisture content during settling. Thus if you come along later and retrofit in different insulation and don't allow the brick to breath or see the same temperature/humidity variations it is accustomed to it will start drying, cracking and crumbling....this is an issue in insulation of old warehouses where we want the brick 'look' but better insulation....usually doing non-specialised insulation on the inside of old brick buildings is a bad idea and leads to more rapid degradation.

Comment: ...fewer people waiting at bus stops (because less time has elapsed since the late bus passed).  Ultimately, the bus in the rear catches up to the bus ahead of it. However, it can be difficult for the rear bus to pass the one ahead of it, because it also has to stop at all the bus stops to drop off passengers.

For people waiting at bus stops, this leads to huge gaps in bus arrivals. If a bus is schedule every 10 minutes, its common that two buses will come every 20 minutes and that the front bus will be too crowded to board and the rear bus has many empty seats. Having streets with multiple bus routes makes the problem worse. 

This bunching problem has pretty much capped ridership on TheBus system at about 70 million rides per year since the early 1980's. It's not that the City can't add more buses, its just that every bus it adds makes the bunching problem worse, leading to slower average travel speeds, and higher per rider costs as the ratio of bus drivers to passengers decreases.

Comment: From Henri Nouwen, on 21st Century Mysticism:"Jesus was a revolutionary, who did not become an extremist, since he did not offer an ideology, but Himself. He was also a mystic, who did not use his intimate relationship with God to avoid the social evils of his time, but shocked his milieu to the point of being executed as a rebel...Every real revolutionary is challenged to be a mystic at heart, and he who walks the mystical way is called to unmask the illusory quality of human society. Mysticism and revolution are two aspects of the same attempt to bring about radical change. No mystic can prevent himself from becoming a social critic, since in self-reflection he will discover the roots of a sick society. Similarly, no revolutionary can avoid facing his own human condition, since in the midst of his struggle for a new world he will find that he is also fighting his own reactionary fears and false ambitions." 

Henri Nouwen

Comment: Oh, BS.  "Supervising up to" 60 inmates?  You mean by putting them on lockdown in their cells all day? And how many of those alleged 60 actually need medical or other monitoring?  For those of you that don't know, putting an inmate on suicide watch in prison is more likely than not to make the inmate want to kill himself. The DOC  isolates the despairing inmate inside an all-glass cage with a concrete floor and no furniture.They take away every bit of clothing and leave him with a sleeping bag that doubles as wearing apparel. The lights are on 24/7.  They may restrict the inmate's ability to move. The inmate isn't allowed contact with anyone who actually cares about him - a family member, for example-for support. The DOC leaves him on display like that, with so-called mental health technicians coming around every so often to stand outside his cage and ask if he feels suicidal.  99.99% of inmates lie about their mental condition so they can escape suicide watch hell.

Comment: Every chance I get, I like to remind people that a sales tax disproportionately affects lower income citizens. It's not a "fair" tax and it is not "equal." 

When you need new headlights for your car, no one checks to see your income level before assigning the sales tax. A person of low income ends up paying a larger portion of their disposable income than a wealthy person. 

There's no sliding scale on sales tax, but there sure is on income tax. While those words may be a boogeyman expression in Alaska, so too was "cutting the PFD" aka the "third rail in Alaskan politics." 

Either we hurt poor people disproportionately, or we make the most fortunate members of our society shoulder the burden. It's about % not $'s folks.

“What a nice sound that is. Are they playing that for you or for me?” Trump said smarmingly, before turning to the audience. “They’re playing that in honor of his ratings”
The bugle call was “Retreat,” which signifies the lowering of the American flag on a military installation.
Although Trump attended a military high school, and wraps himself in the flag,remained unmoving and unaware of the music’s meaning.

Comment: Probably not.  The commercial fishing season was moved back to July 1 long before this. There may have been some 60' personal use nets (the regs change a lot, I can't remember what was used when), but their impact on kings was negligible.  

But if your point is that commercial fishing can't be solely blamed for the poor state of the fishery today, you are correct.  Both runs were healthy in the 80's; both are a mess now. Pointing a finger at commercial fishing ignores the fact that there's been no commercial effort on the first run since the 70's, yet it's arguably in worse shape than the second run (which has been commercially fished every year).   

Rebuilding and preserving the runs should be a priority, based on a comprehensive review of spawning and rearing habitat, water quality, user group pressure/harvest efficiency, etc. Anyone proclaiming that eliminating a single user group will solve the problem (KRSA, Joe Connors) is using your gullibility to line their own pockets.

Along comes Crowdfunding that democratizes lending by uniting consumers and entrepreneurs in need of capital. It also has the potential of ending the business practice of usury that has created a nation burdened with too much debt.

Crowdfunding with it's disruptive formula utilizing the Internet and social media has the power to change the direction of the present business obsession of the bottom line and profits, to a humanistic business model.

"Buyer Beware" will still be the dictum of due diligence, but direct involvement of starting businesses that benefit you will be empowering, and in this case, taste great!

Comment: Comments generate page views which are used to set rates for advertising, so generating them has economic benefit for the paper. When you post a comment here now, you are presented with a series of comments to "rate" whether they are "good" (whatever the flock that means) or "civil." The latter is a test to see if you are voting the way the bot wants you to vote. If you diverge from that, you are presented with a series of warnings, and eventually "restricted." By tweaking the parameters of the bot, it's possible to gradually winnow a group of commenters to ones who all vote the same way. Trump would like to put the whole political system on something like this. I heard Putin uses it, but instead of restricting you, someone comes around and shoots you in the knees. You've heard of Artificial Intelligence, or AI, this is Artificial Stupid, or AS.

Comment: Opinions, even expressed disrespectfully, are part of politics.  But outright defamation should not be tolerated.  Mr. Roland’s letter states as fact that I have done no city volunteer work “prior or since (sic) 2015”.  This statement is false.

My volunteer community work includes city, regional and international.
1993 through 2016 my wife and I have raised funds for local charities through our coffee shop.
2004 through 2013 I volunteered for the City of Redmond Parks and Recreation as a coach and umpire.
As president of tennis club I helped organize major charity events that served eastside organizations. 
In 2007 along with co-workers I received the Martin Luther King Group Humanitarian Award for volunteer work we did over a 5 year period.
January 2005 Iflew to Sri Lanka with my son to conduct logistics support for Tsunami victims.
I am disappointed a letter like this was written in support of my opponent and shared on his web site. Many of us give to our community in many ways.

Comment: There are a lot of sources out there if you are truly interested. For example:
https://www.forbes.com/sites/johntharvey/2012/10/05/government-vs-business/#7c8bfa342a54
Just to get to the main crux of the issue:
"Bear in mind, first, that “efficiency” in the private sector means profit. Hence, to ask that the government be run like a business is tantamount to asking that the government turn a profit. The problem in a nutshell, is that not everything that is profitable is of social value and not everything of social value is profitable. Reality TV, pornography, fashion, sports, and gambling are all of questionable social value, but each is quite profitable and exists in the private sector."
What determines good business is a completely different thing from what determines good governance.
Then you have differences in "customer base." Business has some control over who they cater to. Government does not.
DT's current lesson: Business can be restructured fairly easily.  Government cannot.

Comment: Not really.
Some of the groups that have tried this have drilled in areas that are already prone to earthquakes, so, now, by adding water, under pressure, you are providing a lubricant. IOW, they were stupid. 
Another group in Australia tried the 'Hot Rocks' approach, which was to drill multiple wells from different sites, and then inject in the middle. Now, in this case, these wells went below granite, but, the problem became that injection was difficult. 

So, now, we have a heated seam that has multiple wells running horizontally with upwards of a mile or more spread between them. In addition, these have already been fracked and the oil sucked out. So, now by running a SINGLE well down the middle of these and either putting it in the seam or below, they can inject water and have it heated up. Note that the water is simply replacing the oil that was there. In addition, by pulling from well A, then well C, then B, then D, they gain the most energy. Great way to reuse these wells.

Comment: "The Big Island’s mobile slaughter unit still has logistical hurdles. The facility is capable of processing down to quarters, but lacks the ability to cut and wrap. The co-op has experienced delays in bringing on a USDA-certified inspector."
.
Inspected by whom? SOP's written by whom? Who inspects and grades the meat?  What is the procedure if an abscess is revealed during slaughter? 
.
How are the animals restrained and incapacitated prior to exsanguination?  Subsequent to slaughter what is the disposition of the offal, blood, hide and bone? Where and how are the sides and quarters inspected and stored. 
.
Why a mobile abattoir? The Big Island  is in reality a small place. Transporting animals to a fixed facility is not recreating the Chisholm Trail.  The entire concept is illogical, inefficient, uneconomical and poses immense challenges for sanitation.

Comment: Your Grade 4, 1960's  version of Columbus is pretty lame.
Bartholomew De Las Casas transcribed Columbus’s journal and wrote his own History of the Indies.
Of Columbus and his fellow Spaniards, he writes: 
"Endless Testimonies… prove the mild and pacific temperament of the natives… But our work was [to] ravage, kill, mangle and destroy; small wonder, then, if they tried to kill one of us now and then… The admiral, it is true was blind as those who came after him, and he was so anxious to please the King that he committed irreparable crimes against the Indians…"
Columbus "discovered" a land that been inhabited by millions of people for thousands of years. That's not unlike if you go to France and say, "Wow, I just found a new land."
Should Columbus be revered for the above? Doubtful.
Should existing statues be taken down. Difficult to answer. But people are not "looney tunes" for thinking about these questions.

Comment: You seem to favour absolutes. I don't. My comment did not blame all parents, but nor will I call it a "bad education system". There are positives along with the negatives. No system is perfect

Over 15 years+, my three children moved through the public school system (French immersion stream). Overall, I would say the quality of teaching follows the Pareto Principle variation of 80-60-20, but closer to 30-40-30.  30% of teachers are outstanding, 40% are okay, 30% are disasters. Comment: Bill:  IMO, the first step to improvement in anything is to identify the problems which need to be addressed....to identify the "shortcomings", then to plan and take actions toward improvement.  "looking at the negative" does not, IMO, lead to depression...."dwelling on the negative" does.  If my car won't start I can whine about it, I can say "or well" and start walking, or I can say "geez, I'd better fix it" and do so.  The first, indeed, leads to depression; the second ignores the problem and the third is a positive quest for a solution.  I'll take the third option every time.  regards, Gary Crum

Comment: Americans have much to be proud of, John Glenn and their space program at the top of the list

Interestingly, at the Challenger Space  Centre in phoenix AZ, there is a small display dedicated to Canada's Jim Chamberlin, a key engineer on the AVRO Arrow program who, along with 25 other Canadian engineers, were scooped up by NASA for the Gemini and Apollo programs.  Their contribution was legion. I recall a picture there of several NASA astronauts, John Glenn included, posed with Chamberlin et al at some sort of recognition event. 

"Chamberlin was head of engineering for Project Mercury, chief designer and NASA's first Project Manager for the Gemini spacecraft built by McDonnell Aircraft, and then troubleshooter on Apollo, Chamberlin played an instrumental role in creating and implementing the first three generations of American crewed spacecraft." (wikipedia).  He and Glenn were 'joined at the hip' as they say and Chamberlin was the unsung hero :)

Comment: If you have Medicare or Medicaid, there are Federal limits to what the doctor can charge you. It’s about 35% of their usual charges. If you go to an in-network physician, again, there are limits to what you can be charged. People are starting to wise up to how this game is played and are now finally starting to inquire about whether the doctor they are going to see is in network. No hidden costs, no surprises. The only unknown ahead of time is which level of care you are going to get charged. Easier problems should be a level one or two. Medium level problems a three. More complicated problems are a level 4 or 5. It’s impossible for a receptionist to know which level of care you are going to need. Do your research about preferred, in-network providers and that will protect you as much as possible from high charges. Oh, if you think your problem really was an easy one and for a 10 minute exam, you should NOT be getting charged a level 4or 5 visit. Speak to the doctor about the charge!!!

Comment: Parliamentary reform? Thankfully, Justin has let that slip away and virtually disappear. The country would waste years and increase its political nastiness by trying to accomplish a goal that is impossible. Has their been a great calling from the people for such a reform? It was "mentioned" in the last election - by a party that has now abandoned the idea.  Are the two opposition parties making much noise about it? Nope. Also, parliamentary reform involves two chambers. There have been many Canadians wanting to 'reform" the Senate for decades -  and many others wanting to shut it down, to abolish it. The ideas of complete change to a system of government that has not been a failure is not appealing to me. Such an attempt would consume our politicians - and our media - for years. It would also involve election(s) and referendum(s). All goes well here.
P.S. If we do start opening that "can of worms" let's deal with the Senate FIRST.

Comment: The reader could stick to the e-series only, or use a strategy of having the e-series as the base of monthly savings (fractional shares allowed), then annually or semi-annually converting money to cheaper ETFs.

Especially within a registered plan (no capital gains tax to pay), it is unwise to keep chasing new investment products without selling the old ones. This leads to "diworsification" - a collection of too many products that are almost guaranteed to underperform the markets.  This is made even worse with advice like: "It might make sense to drop a 5-per-cent weighting in one of these new ETFs into this reader’s portfolio".

Comment: Troubling and inflammatory decision by the Trudeau government. I find it useful to compare this situation with that of William Sampson, who was imprisoned in a Saudi prison for 3 years, from 2000 to 2003.  He never received a dime, and received almost no support whatsoever from the Canadian government. Indeed, the Canadian government went so far as to question him as to whether he was being tortured in the presence of his Saudi torturers. He attempted to sue his Saudi torturers, but this was denied by the UK Justice system. He never attempted to sue the Canadian government. The difference between Sampson and Khadr is that he was a biochemist and cinematoragher, who Amnesty International (a great Khadr supporter by the way) termed as being abandoned by the Canadian government for a crime he very likely didn't commit, and which to this day remains uninvestigated by the Canadian authorities. This decision to reward Khadr is selective and pusillaminous.

Comment: "DPP responded in comments to the commission that Monsanto, which plans to give about 20 acres to the National Park Service and another small parcel to the Board of Water Supply, didn’t offer a compelling reason for not preserving 558 acres that DPP said includes land that produced the highest levels of sugar cane during Hawaii’s plantation era."

Only the owner can make a evaluation of land because DPP doesn't have the expertise. Comment: The Globe has created a lot of controversy with its story. Unfortunately this will not result in more sexual assault charges being laid, much less convictions.

As I understand it most sexual assault cases involve very little hard evidence unless there is violence that leaves an indelible mark or if the predator is a serial offender. In addition I understand that many victims do not report their complaints to the police promptly. After 48 hours there is little chance of catching the offender (this applies to all crimes).

The police are therefor in a tough position. They could lay many more charges but crown attorneys  would likely drop most for lack of evidence. The defendants would then sue for slander since sexual assault charges can result in permanent loss of reputation and financial harm.

Comment: Absolutely EXCELLENT advice! Bravo! This is a well timed article and I hope it saves a lot of troubles for a lot of people.
I've tramped the mountains and valleys of Alaska for sixty-some odd years and never once had any emergency kit...but I sure as heck should have and I don't know why I didn't need one. I was never accused of being agile, that's for sure! All I ever had was a a Bic, bug spray, a compass and a hunting knife. And of course a trusty bear gun. 
Dad always said "If you get lost climb a tree and look around for anything you can recognize. Fire three shots. (HELP) and if all else fails, make smoke but for God sake try not to burn down the forest. Mainly, do not panic! "  He always reminded me that people usually take a longer step with one foot so they end up going in circles. 
I'd like to make the suggestion to always tell someone else where you're going and when you expect to be back. Even if you are with someone else. You never know what might happen.

Comment: The trick to the 2 minute shower: Buy a large round plastic basin big enough to stand in comfortably and small enough to fit in your shower. Stand in the basin, switch on the water, wet yourself all over and wet your facecloth or sponge. Turn water off. Wash yourself all over using the water on your body and the small amount of water collected in the basin. Turn shower on briefly to rinse most of the soap off and to wet your hair. Turn shower off. Shampoo hair. Turn shower on, rinse hair and ensure that all soap and shampoo is off body. Turn shower off. The 2 minute shower in not "only spend 2 minutes in the shower", it's "only have the water running for 2 minutes".

Comment: Chase, with all due respect, it might be you that does not understand the mining law of 1872. the law established rights to claims and established prices for the lands those claims were set on. it in no way established responsibility for cleanup, but rather established the method or how claims were processed. this prevented "claim jumping" and established who owned what and where. a claim had to spend a certain amount of money each year, if memory serves it was $100 annually. after showing this for a period of time, 5 years I believe, they could apply for a patent on that claim, by which the miner would then own that land. thus the term "patented claim" versus "unpatented claim". now, if the miner filed a claim that was never patented then the land would revert back to federal control. the government in  1977 passed the Surface Control and Reclamation Act (SMCRA) to ensure that mining companies would restore the lands after the mining. more to come.

Comment: A 20 percent tariff on imports from Mexico will be paid by Americans in the form of higher prices.  Mexico itself need not experience any downside at least in the short term.  What the tariff would do is to raise the prices Americans pay for imported Mexican goods and thus allow higher paid American workers at American manufacturers to compete and over the long term displace Mexican imports.  Americans would have to tighten their belts to pay the price of American made goods, but the long term good would be retention of more manufacturing in the USA.  Mexico can look to the entire rest of the world to retarget its exports and certainly a tariff would not motivate domestic manufacture of a considerable percentage of current Mexican imports.  Enhance American manufacturing.  Minimally, impact Mexico.

Comment: It is troubling that the authors covertly snipe at nuclear generation, implying that nuclear is a major cause of the high costs faced by Ontario ratepayers. I urge readers to visit the IESO website where you can view demand and supply in near real-time. On any given day, you will see that we have surplus generation roughly equivalent to the amount produced by wind generators that is routinely exported at a loss. You will also see how unpredictable wind generation is. Logically, managing that kind of unpredictability is more costly. It is absurd that, through subsidies, we pay more for a kilowatt hour of wind-generated power only to then sell it at a discount to competing jurisdictions. It's the renewables forced on us by the Liberals that have driven costs through the roof. Nuclear is zero emissions, reliable, and way more cost-effective. In short, it works while renewables do not. How on earth will we replace 60% of generation using renewables without bankrupting the province?

Comment: I completely disagree with you.  Everyone should be prudent with their finances.  Increase costs for borrowing should trigger at least some review of strategy even if it saves you $20 a month.  For example:  should I switch to fixed if I have variable?  Should I allocate more money to paying off debt?  Should I re-visit my investments?  e.g. sell some holdings and buy others based on who is going to benefit from this.  Typically, companies that are paying a high dividend or distribution tend to suffer from a raise in higher interest rates because investors move out of those investments since they are a little less attractive.    There is a lot to consider and changes like these should not be shrugged off with the attitude of, "Oh, I'll be fine".

Since World War II, a shift of a few thousand votes in 1, 2, or 3 states would have elected a 2nd-place candidate in 6 of the 18 presidential elections

Comment: Spencer wrote  in his Principles of Biology, "This survival of the fittest, which I have here sought to express in mechanical terms, is that which Mr. Darwin has called 'natural selection', or the preservation of favoured races in the struggle for life." Darwin liked the phrase, as did  Alfred Russel Wallace, who had developed the theory of natural selection independently of Darwin (but Darwin published first -- after being made aware of Wallace's work). Darwin himself used it in some of the later editions of Origin of Species, meaning "better designed for an immediate, local environment".

Unfortunately, Spencer and some of his followers took the phrase in what they called a moral sense,  as an ethical precept that sanctioned cut-throat economic competition. Some of the more extreme Social Darwinists said that the poor should not be helped, since it would be aiding the "less fit" in surviving. They claimed that social caste was determined by natural superiority.

Comment: It's a very complicated issue that others have already written words on here and elsewhere.  IMHO, comments here are best based on quick points - not big essay, deep topic discussions.  I will say this, the solution involves a lot more than saying whether we should cut more trees or not.  It gets down to the very foundation of how our society believes we should interact with the natural world.  'Give and take' is part of the natural process, but there's a balance.  Our culture (not just the economy and not just forestry) is way beyond that balance.  Unless that changes, it's all band-aids on a bigger issue and I wouldn't expect much change toward the healthier direction.

Comment: Isn't this so like the G&M and even the Toronto Star to pretend no one saw this coming?  If neither of this media sources saw it coming, it's because none of their editors saw the importance of having an Energy Report on staff (they still don't).  Therefore, when Mike Harris issued The MacDonald Report during the summer of 1996, all both newspapers did was rehash and publish--without question--the news releases prepared by the Premier's office.  None of their reporters bothered to read the Appendix of The MacDonald Report.  The Appendix explained in very concise terms how the Province's bean counters figured that selling off Ontario Hydro and opening the grid to out-of-Province supply (always more costly) would lower the price of electricity in Ontario.  The reasoning was rubbish, of course.  The core of the reasoning offered was that an outsider would purchase one of Ontario Hydro's generating units and sell electricity to Ontarians at less than the prevailing price of electricity.

Comment: Foster:  Don't kid yourself.  Saying Tramadol is harmless because it's a SYNTHETIC opioid is like saying Fentanyl is harmless because it's a synthetic.  Tramadol was originally billed as having a lower addiction potential than other opioids which is why it wasn't originally scheduled as a controlled drug, but the truth is it works on the same opioid receptors as morphine or oxycontin does.  If it has any lower abuse potential it's just because it's less likely at normal doses to make you "high", but it has the same addictive potential as any other opioid drug, and is hardly equivalent to "baby aspirin" or other NSAID drugs.

Comment: Have to weigh pros and cons of any choices, and of course with electric vs ICE there are many pros and cons to consider.  I think it is ridiculous to see EV ownership as 'virtue signalling.'  That may be true for a subset of holier-than-thou EV owners.  However I am not a person very concerned with the environment and I would love to have an EV - they are just smoother, quieter, less maintenance hassle and here in BC a lot cheaper to fuel (plentiful cheap hydropower).  I live in Victoria thus I am hardly driving any distance, so range just is not an issue.  There is also the fact that many EVs are a lot peppier than ICE vehicles - those motors give out all their torque instantly, which is a superb benefit in stop-start traffic.  However weighing pros and cons for myself ... I am more inclined to buy a small hybrid next as they are a good compromise - cheaper MSRP than EV and stingy sippers of fuel.

Comment: As an idea of how ridiculous it can be, I’ll never forget the day at work when I walked into my office, and saw three files about six inches thick on my desk.  There was a note on top from my boss, to come see him about this guy, as he was being released onto supervision in the next few days.  When I got into his office we went over several things in regards to this individual.  As I was leaving his office, he stopped me and said don’t forget the rest of his files!  There were two more boxes full of more files.  This guy had been in and out of jail, on and off probation, and parole (which can have concurrent or consecutive times), had multiple cases, and even some federal time dating from the 80’s to 2000’s. Talk about a time accounting nightmare.  He wasn’t the only one I saw like that either. I don’t think anyone should be in prison more than they are supposed to, but it’s a complicated mess and it’s going to occasionally happen.  I also think much of this lays on the offender.

Comment: Gun show loophole? No such loophole exists. Everyone who purchases a firearm at a gun show booth fills out the same BATF form 4473 and undergoes the same FBI background check as if they were in a gun shop making the purchase. A call is made to the FBI right from the booth and the information on the form is sent. The buyer's ID is checked and sent. The FBI performs their check and responds with either "Proceed", "Hold" or "Deny". Any response other than "Proceed" and the buyer cannot complete the transaction and is sent home empty handed. The ONLY case where a background check is not required for purchases is a private transaction between two parties (ex: I sell you my gun) and those can occur anywhere. Even then many gun owners will use the same techniques gun stores do to determine a buyer's eligibility when conducting a private sale. by the way, any law requiring a BG check for private purchase is unenforceable. Even the FBI says so.

Comment: I worked as a mental health specialist for the county for 17 years.   With 20 years post graduate experience,  a Masters Degree,  and at the top salary step I earned a salary the same as my wife, who is a letter carrier for the post office.   The turnover in professional positions at the county mental health clinic is extraordinary because skilled people can go elsewhere for better compensation and a more functional organization.    I was lied to, disrespected, and have no trust in county administration.  Since I retired a little more than two years ago,  there remain just a very few colleagues who are still there.   If lane county doesn't stay competitive with other counties and other local providers,  many good people leave,  and despite the comments here,   are not easily replaced.   If you have a family member needing and deserving high quality care, and continuity of care, you may find out it does make a difference to you.

Comment: Take a trip to Amsterdam.

OK, Toronto isn't Amsterdam, and a Toronto solution will be different.

However, in Amsterdam, there is a train station in the basement of Schiphol.  The train will get you into downtown Amsterdam in under fifteen minutes.  Same station can get you trains to other Dutch cities like Rotterdam and Hague, as well as other European cities.
 
In Amsterdam, walk out the front of the terminal, and there is both bus rapid transit and regular bus service readily available.

And while Amsterdam doesn't have an example of a subway, all you need to do is go to London Heathrow to see how that can work.  Multiple stations for the London Underground so you can get pretty much anywhere in the city.

And I am sure there are other cities that have similar hubs.

Happy travelling.

Comment: My father started farming in the mid-1930s and continued until his retirement in 1980. He always told me that the two driest years of his time on the farm were 1936 and 1961. My brother now farms that same land and he has experienced 3 years that were even drier than 1936 and 1961. However during those drought years my brother produced crop yields that approached what would have been a good average yield for my father in a good moisture year.

That shows just how farming practices have changed in 30 years.

Interestingly, the only total crop failure that my father ever experienced (1950) was caused by excessive moisture. Torrential rains in August, September, and October of that year made his fields totally unworkable. Dad was not even able to swathe his grain that year.

My brother has now farmed that same land for almost 40 years and he has never experienced a crop failure. This year is looking like a real bumper crop for him, although he has yet to combine his canola.

What is the safe distance from a well blowout, explosion, and fire there Plainthinker?   According to recent peer-reviewed evidence from  the University of Pittsburgh Medical School the minimum safe distance obtained through thermal modeling on unprotected human skin is over 2000 feet, while the minimum safe distance to a oil industry hazmat leak is between a half-mile and 2.5 miles depending on the chemical involved, the size of the spill, the amount spilled, and the weather at the time of the spill.

Comment: Here's another WWII story:

My father was probably saved by those bombs (as were many other Canadian soldiers).  Dad had orders from the Canadian Army in the summer of 1945 to go to the US to begin training on US equipment in preparation for the Invasion of Japan.  (Apparently all allied forces had agreed to only use US Army equipment for the invasion.) 

He was in the Royal Canadian Dragoons (Armoured Car Regiment).  They were to be part of the British Commonwealth Corps in Operation Coronet, the invasion of Honshu to take Tokyo.  The allies estimated that Operation Coronet would be a beach landing 3 - 4x larger than the Normandy Invasion. Just before they were to leave the US dropped those bombs and the war ended. 

As terrible as this poor women's experience was, millions of allies and Japanese were saved by the quick end to that war.

Comment: "Entry-level economics teaches us, however, that there is no relationship between cost and price."

I stopped reading at this point.  Complete nonsense.  Rubbish.  A company is entirely constrained by the cost of its product.  Imagine the company pays $3 for their widget (after all discounts and rebates are accounted for) and tries to make a profit by reselling it at $2.50.  If anyone thinks they can make a profit this way, don't go into business.  Companies survive by selling their product a prices higher than their net cost.  The difference must also pay for overhead, salaries, insurance, etc. etc.  So if the profit margin is a couple of percent before measure 97, the company must raise prices or go out of business (assuming it can't fire people to reduce cost).

I suspect that Mr. McKinney's company is not subject to the tax so of course he wants his competition to face it.

Comment: In thinking about this tax law change I was having trouble deciding whether it was a good or bad change.  Obviously anything that raises taxes is going to have some negative consequences and, in this case, it will result in lower take-home pay.  On the flip side this change should even out and simplify the tax code by disallowing a "businesses within a business" sort of structure.

After thinking it through a bit it hit my why I was struggling with this: It ignores the root problem in the first place.

The real problem is that we have this "small business tax rate" that punishes businesses for growing.  Not only does it complicate the tax code but it causes taxes to increase when businesses do the very thing we want them to do: be successful and create jobs.

The real answer is to eliminate the small business rate and lower the regular rate.  THAT is how you keep the tax code equal and fair.

We know that climate change has been going on some 4+B years, without human help.

However, a 2016 survey by the American Meteorological Society on who & what is causing climate change is interesting. Of the some 8000 members polled, only 53% bother to respond, which says something right there. That a significant number think it's not worth their time.

Of those who did respond ~ 67% think humans are the primary climate changers, & about 28% think that some or most climate change is natural. 

So it seems you might put more effort into gathering some scientific facts, & less of the political "noise".

Comment: The Supremes don't 𝒉𝒂𝒗𝒆 to take the case.  They don't 𝒉𝒂𝒗𝒆 to make a decision one way or another.  In fact, it can be argued based on custom and their own rules, they 𝒄𝒂𝒏'𝒕 take the case.  Doesn't mean they won't -- just makes it less likely.

Every court, right up through two different Federal appeals courts, has upheld the stay.  (The two appeals courts faulted the ban on two different legal grounds, which would make the DOJ's work twice as difficult.)  The key point is that the court rulings all fell on the same side, against the ban.  It's surpassingly rare for the Court to take up a case where there/s no conflict between appeals court rulings.  

Trump seems to feel that all he has to do is ask, and the Court will accept the case.  That's simply not so, and the choice of options in this poll should reflect this fact.

Comment: "How can they force you to license to a competitor? "

Sure they can. That's because a patent holder total power of license is a concept unique to America, land of free competition. Most foreign countries do not accept the concept. Note that we are talking only patent (invention), not technologies or implementation. A invention, any invention, must be available to all, at a price of course. It promotes competition. It is up to the buying of license to actually build something out of the patents, which is by no means a sure thing. 

Qualcomm is also accused of overcharging royalties. where royalties of its chips are based not on price of chips but on the 'value' of the end products that contain the chips. Qualcomm can define value anyway it wants. Qualcomm is accused of 'stuffing' all kinds of 'values' not connected to the chips to inflate royalties. 

I think Qualcomm copied a lot of nasty business practices from the heydays of an arrogant Microsoft.

Comment: Don't know about Ontario, but here in BC, teacher pensions are fully funded. The employer contribution roughly matches teacher contributions. 

When commenting upon teacher pensions keep in mind that employer and teacher contributions fund only a small proportion of teacher pension payments. The majority is funded through investment income. This is because teachers are required to contribute to pensions right from the first month of contract employment. After 30+ years, this contribution has grown a substantial amount. 

I hope that all citizens will have the greater benefits of this kind of system (like CPP). This especially applies to small business owners. As they are often in a risky occupation (restaurant etc), I don't understand why they take a position against a system like the CPP or teacher pensions.  It seems to me they would do much better if they (and all their competitors) were required to contribute to a similar pension plan. 
  I'd welcome thoughtful explanations.

Comment: Here is a simple test you can take to decide if this law would benefit you:

1) Are you extremely wealthy?

If you answered yes, congratulations, this law will benefit you financially.  If not, proceed to question 2.

2) Are you pretty wealthy?  

If you answered yes, this law will probably benefit you, depending on how many family members or dependents you may need to help financially after this bill is passed.  If no, please proceed to question 3.

3) Are you ever going to need health care for any reason?

If you answered yes, this bill will probably be very detrimental to you financially.  If not, this bill will probably save you money, since you are likely to decide that insurance costs too much and you need to hope that you never need health care.

Comment: Oh Bill gets it all right. He understood what a conflict of interest was when he was a partner in one of the Big 4 accounting firms. There you have to check whether any investment is permitted before buying it, register all purchases, and sell when instructed if the firm got audit business from that company. It was a big deal. Moreover, there was no way indirect ownerships were exempted. All the investments owned by you, your significant other and childen who were financially dependent on you were covered.

He gets it and broke the anti-avoidance rule in the Conflict of Interest Act that says you cannot take any step to avoid application of the Act. That is precisely what he did when he transferred his investment in Morneau Shapell to his holding company. That should be the focus of the probe. So the loophole is one thing, planning to use the loophole is the his violation.

Comment: With the exception of Metlakatla. Being the only federally recognized reservation in Alaska, they can and do "blue" ticket people, both native and non-native,  off the island. However, they have havea tribal code of laws, a tribal court and tribal police. 
No one can decide to throw someone off the reservation, it has to go through the tribal court and approved by the tribal counsel. It is perfectly legal as far as federal and Alaska law goes because the person or people are given the opportunity to have a hearing.
On most reservations, non-enrolled members, native and non-native, have to have a tribal member "sign" or sponsor them while on the reservation.  Permission given as long as peopleagree to follow the tribal laws and federal laws. 
More traditional forms of "punishment" are similar to the circle sentencing courts in Canadian villages and in a few areas of Alaska, such as Kake, Alaska. 
Interesting information can be found by Googling. The Alaska Judicial Council has info too.

We can cut our way to balance right now with an immediate 2 billion dollar budget cut this year.  Or we can gain significant relief by not inflation proofing the Permanent Fund and completely eliminating the individual PFD.  Of course neither of these scenarios is going to be politically possible or economically sane; however, that demonstration reveals the scope and severity of our fiscal situation.

Comment: Like Clement Hall, above, I was also criticized for my unwillingness to prescribe narcotics for chronic or recurring conditions. For the last 16 years of my career I was responsible for 100 residents of a nursing home, average age 84. Pain was assessed on a daily basis and I had the help of experienced nursing and pharmacy staff to make sure that pain issues were adequately addressed. Nevertheless, articles in the medical literature started appearing in the 1990s (funded by pharma) saying 80% of nursing home patients were suffering "severe uncontrolled pain". This was certainly false in my nursing home. From 2000 onwards, however, increasing numbers of new residents were already on long term narcotics at the time of admission. By 2015 almost 50% of all new admissions to our units were on narcotics, some on doses of 100mg morphine a day or higher. We were almost always able to reduce or eliminate these medications with no noticeable increase in pain. But it could take a year or more.

Comment: I understand what you are saying, and I understand why the drafters don't ask in terms of "sexual assault," but your analogy doesn't quite work, because not everything in that question IS sexual assault, whereas hitting and punching ARE usually assaults.  As in the example I gave: suspecting that someone may have attempted to have unwanted sexual contact.  If you are trying to avoid legal phrases, why use one like "sexual contact" in the question?  Why not say, for example, "did someone touch or try to touch your breasts when you did not want that person to?  If so, do you think that person knew that you did not want that to happen?"  I think the law actually requires only recklessness as to lack of consent -- but my point is that newspaper articles should not use legal terms to describe the results of surveys that don't track the law.  //  I will read all the questions, if I can find them online, so we don't get stuck in some discussion loop here.  Thanks for taking time to respond!

Comment: "There would" be NOTHING for mutual fund advisers to report if the MER fees were excluded. I suspect what is excluded is is the costs of the funds over and above the MER such as trading fees that the fund itself incurs. Or perhaps you mean the adviser will report only the portion of the MER that goes to the advisor and not the share kept by the mutual fund company."

The second sentence of what I quoted above is true. Only the trailer fee component of the MER is reported; the rest of the MER is excluded from the report, which could be very misleading to uninformed investors. Reports will also summarize transaction and administrative fees. 

See this link for a sample report: https://www.ific.ca/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Model-Report-on-Charges-and-Compensation.pdf/10338/

Comment: Yes! College endowments and other trusts that are managed with an infinite time horizon use the POMV approach. The Permanent Fund should do the same. I would suggest, though, that the drawdown be 4% per year, not 5%. The smaller figure is commonly used by trusts that do not anticipate new contributions from outside the trust's revenue stream. I think such a trust is a closer model to the Perm Fund than an endowment drawing down at 5% but which has a development office bringing in new capital into the fund. We are going to have to stop new deposits to the fund.

Comment: Alaskans received a good education along with other services such as public safety when the total state government budget was at $350 million. My parents paid state income taxes, contributed to booster clubs for sports and gave us a good life. We have to adjust. We can buy a good used car instead of a new one. A good stew will keep us instead of steak every night. The state government can cut spending to close the budget gap and pass a spending cap. Governor Walker says it time to make the tough decisions. Taking the permanent fund is not making a tough decision. It's taking the easy way out for state government and big business. Not Alaskans. We have survived bust times before. We will survive this time. Yes. There will be another boom. This time we should put the windfall into the CBR - Constitutional Budget Reserve account.

Comment: Ms. Patkotak, thank you for this important column. I also agree that the overwhelming majority of people in this country are good, decent, hardworking people who are not themselves bigoted. The problem, however, is not individual racism but institutional racism. When the levers of power are predominantly accessible to select classes of Americans -- and denied to others -- discriminatory practices are built into the very structure of that society. What we saw in the election of Donald Trump was a panicked grab for those levers by a class of Americans who not only feels their grip slipping, but also spies those "other" classes coming up fast. This is what the "Again" in MAGA is all about. The vehemence with which some commenters on this thread deny that fact is proof of the primacy of institutional norms to guide individual behavior, even for otherwise good, decent, hardworking people.

Comment: Humans are animals in the scientific sense. As such the three most powerful instincts we have are to ingest sustenance, excrete waste, and procreate. During the vast majority of our history as a species, we had a very short lifespan so we evolved to be sexually active at an age that was, at the time, nearly middle age. 

With the advent of hygiene and antibiotics, we have drastically increased that lifespan. This happened only a second ago in the scale of human existence so we have not had time to evolve to the new lifespans and now we have 7 billion plus humans on the planet. 

Sex is not a choice per se, it is a biological imperative. Thus it is unhelpful to suggest not having sex as an answer. It is everyone's responsibility to do all we can to prevent unplanned pregnancy because none of us are exempt from the results. Colorado has proven that providing IUDs at little or no cost has reduced teen pregnancy be 40% and abortions by 35%. This is a solution, abstinence is not.

Comment: About the only good thing one can say about the CPP system is that it isn't as much of a disaster as most other government pension plans in other countries around the world.

There are a number of things that CPP gets "right", but there are a LOT of things that CPP gets "wrong" to "very wrong".  A lot of this is due to historical baggage.  CPP, as it was originally designed in 1965, was a DISASTER!  It was a horrible system to start with and, rather than fixing things in the late 60's or through the 1970's, it was actually made worse.

Fortunately we have been fixing some of the mistakes of CPP for the past 20 years now, starting with a major overhaul in 1996/97 and continuing through to the changes made in ~2012/13.  Unfortunately there was a BIG hill to climb.

Comment: Many Canadians need to get over their visceral anti-Americanism. Although the partnership between Canada and the United States is sometimes strained, there is still a friendship between our countries that is almost unequaled in the world. We must not allow misplaced national pride to blind us from the undeniable fact that we need American military protection for our country's survival. It is a shame that past and current prime ministers have been willing to sacrifice Canada's defense needs on the altar of political expediency. Although the United States would most likely defend Canada in the event that it is targeted by a foreign aggressor, the best way to guarantee that we are protected is to enter into a joint missile-defense agreement without further delay. Rather than benefit from US military protection by default, Canada needs to pull its own weight within a mutual defense pact.  Puerile political posturing will not save us if the nuclear missiles start flying.

Comment: Great article.  I took a yellow Lab down to John at Hammond's homestead where John  was working in 1977.  He named it York after the man who helped guide the Lewis & Clark expedition. York was a faithful and selfless companion for many years. 
I was the "victim" of one of John's "hikes" on that trip. He grabbed a small day pack and asked if I wanted to go for a walk. He suggested I take some water and perhaps a couple piece of extra clothing. I assumed a rain jacket was what he meant. After about an hour of climbing west I asked where we were heading. He said " twin Lakes" which was where Dick Proenneke built his cabin. It was over a mountain range and maybe 30 miles away. I was not about to make that "hike" and turned back. He kept on going but said for me to
stay right of the creek and I would get back to the homestead. Quite a man.

Comment: Let the automobile and fossil fuel industries pay for the roads. It was their profit whose preference built that system over more sustainable scalable options that we already had. These industries collaborated in disassembling what was, in retrospect, a wisely-conceived urban public transit infrastructure.
I suppose that everyone's hoping driverless will cars help, but I think there's a long-term stability in a larger public system than can be achieved with privately-owned vehicles for a city. Surely, no matter what, there will be a diversity of transit options as time goes on, but we're anemic on some right now. Getting these massive fleets of internal combustion engines out of the civic atmosphere will probably be of great benefit to public health along major roads.

Comment: Dear Mr Ramaphosa,

Many would concur that in an ideal World, all would be richer and more equal. But such wishes and sentiments are meaningless unless anchored in reality. I have spent the past two weeks travelling around Mozambique, a country even more seriously in need of "radical economic growth resulting in a transformed reality for all".

The question that ought to be taxing our minds is - how to actually bring about the rapid, sustained growth that can make a difference?

I know you will have seen and also understood recent academic papers that set out in detail exactly who owns what in South Africa; and you will have noted that already the section our President calls "white monopoly capital" in fact own a relatively small slice of the pie, and that if we are to have meaningful growth the twin engines of foreign capital, and what could be grouped as domestic longterm investment funds must be mobilised; the crux for you is getting the enabling politics set on a supportive course.

Comment: Section 1 of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms states that the Charter "guarantees the rights and freedoms set out in it subject only to such reasonable limits prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society."
The Charter can be overridden so long as it can be justified. A constitutional lawyer could better explain explain this limitation, but here is one link explaining the test that is used to determine whether a constitutional right can be overridden - http://www.chrc-ccdp.gc.ca/historical-perspective/en/browseSubjects/section1.asp
If most citizens resident in an area can no longer afford to buy a home or can no longer afford without an unreasonable amount of debt, and this is in part due to foreign capital, that could in theory be a justifiable reason to limit a Constitutional right.

Comment: "Perspective is how everyone perceives any given event from their point of view, there is no such thing as truth, only perspective."

That's demonstrably false.  Person A believes in gravity.  Person B does not believe in gravity and believes they can fly if they jump off a building.  Guess what?  Only one of them is correct.  Gravity does exist, and you will fall only in one direction because of it.  

Some people believe lava is deadly for humans.  Others believe you can swim in it on a cold day.  Obviously, the truth lies somewhere in the middle right?  Nope, only one of those "perspectives" is correct.  They are not both true and accurate.  

The great thing about science is that you don't have to believe in it for it to be true.  You don't have to believe that bacteria exist, they just do, regardless of your "perspective."  You don't have to believe in atoms, they will still be there regardless of whether or not you believe they are there.  Facts are much different from beliefs.

Comment: Not entirely true.  Yes, human migration, and hegemony are ubiquitous, that is a historical fact.  However, where your argument stumbles is in using this as a reasonable behaviour, especially when done in a particularly aggressive way.
The difference being made from today, to those actions in the past, is that we can be better than that.  All sorts of actions have long-standing in the history of mankind, but this is not an excuse to continue them today and forever.  
There is no going back, per se, but we can learn from our mistakes, and the ongoing damage, can we not?  And if yes, the question is, do we have a moral obligation to mitigate this damage?
Most Canadians would answer "yes", to both of those questions.

Comment: This is so disingenuous & underhanded that the special interest sponsors of this initiative have been allowed to label this as being a corporate income tax.  In no sense of the proper definition, is this an income tax.

An income tax taxes profits ( income ).   This law taxes gross receipts ( sales ), which is far higher than any profit being made..

A Gross Receipts tax is applied to businesses, while, a Sales Tax if collected from the consumer. Either way, the consumer pays.

So all this initiative is trying to do is to trick the people of Oregon into believing that this is not a sales tax, when it really is.  It will just be collected from the corporation you are doing business with, and not you.  So it will basically be a HIDDEN TAX, that you will not notice.

Although you will notice the prices of many things rising, after this is past.

The fact is that flat taxes like this one  hurt the poor the most.   The rich will easily afford this price hike in goods and services,

Comment: I'm not sure what you are referencing when you say "climate data extrapolated over long periods can become completely out of whack."  I don't know of any peer-reviewed scientific papers that are using extrapolated data.  Instead they are using actual data from that time period: think ice cores, tree rings, and drilling cores from lakes, oceans, etc. for starters.  The hard part, initially, was correlating the chemistry of the cores (and the spacing of tree rings) to temperature and CO2 levels.  But that correlation has been nailed down quite well over the years.  
I do understand where you are coming from when you speak of uncertainties, but in terms of climate change there is very little uncertainty with regards to our role in it.  What is more uncertain is exactly how fast and how damaging the consequences of rapid warming will be.  In that regard most of the computer models have been too conservative, unfortunately, and have understated what is actually occurring.

There may be some fear-mongering with the Peak Oil crowd, but I worked for a German Global Energy company (Not GE), for five years and the Old Timers there are fully on board with the problems that will occur of living in a post peak world, as well as many executives in the auto industry (where I work now) are. It may not be in your or my lifetime, but those issues are coming. Electric vehicles will never solve the oil dependent agricultural business that feeds us. Automotive and Energy is responsible for 35% percent of our GDP, not something you should be taking so lightly.

Comment: Let's make the contention of this article a little simpler: by removing the ability for business owners to split their income via dividends distributed to family member-shareholders, business owners are in effect seeing an increase in their personal / family marginal tax rates. In an effort to appear reasonable, the business owner was fine with the last increase (and with progressive taxation in general), but not this one. 

This is a disagreement about the appropriate rate of taxation on marginal income for business owners, rather than a disagreement about progressive taxation itself. 

This article, however, does not make any case about what a reasonable level of taxation is, only that this new higher level is presumably not it. We're left with an emotional appeal (this business owner deserves to profit from their hard work!) without any analysis of what an appropriate level should be.

Comment: Having been personally involved briefly with trying to do business on Umnak with a Canadian rancher, it was a goat rope and but for a period long ago, most of the efforts to make a go of ranching in the Aleutians has been mostly the same story. Though grass fed beef has a market it is not strong enough to carry the high transportation costs involved. Umnak now has five alien species of quadrupeds; reindeer, cattle, horses, sheep and recently added bison. 

As an aside, potentially the next big issue will be what the caribou are doing to Adak. Since the shutting down of NAS Adak, the herd is not being pruned enough and perhaps another Hagemeister is in the making. In neighboring Atka, the reindeer planted there have been well controlled by the population. The best deer I've ever eaten came from Umnak and Atka. Much better than the blacktails of Kodiak/Shuyak.

Comment: When the defense is "yes, there was sexual intercourse, but it was consensual" the usual procedures used to document a "forceable rape"...or, if you prefer, a "stranger" rape are not at issue.  What is at issue is the question of the mutually consensual nature of the act.

These cases of "date rape" or "acquaintance rape" almost never have witnesses and almost always become a "he said" ..."she said"  debate over the consensual or non-consensual issue.  This gets even "messier" when alcohol is involved; and in the majority of these cases it is.  It's important to remember that "at some point" of intoxication a woman is no longer considered legally capable of giving such consent.......i.e., you can't get a woman "falling down drunk", have sex with her, and then say "hey, she didn't say "no"...it was consensual.  "Allegations of rape" ruin lives...true.  Rapes ruin lives too.....and far more often than false allegations of rape.

Comment: Father Elliot was an incredible man and a great friend of our Dad, Mom, and entire family.  In 2008, Father Elliot travelled to Ketchikan to give the Eulogy for my Dad, Father Don Bullock, at St. John's.  Fortunately, we saved the video of Father Elliot's Eulogy which prompted great memories, laughter and tears.  When living in Tanana and working for the FAA in 1977 and 1978, I flew N8221v (the Cessna 180 that belonged to the Church and was either Blue Box 3 or 4) throughout Alaska for Bishop Cochrane, and was frequently asked upon landing if I knew Father Elliot, and to pass greetings from the villages.  Father Elliot was well known throughout Alaska and will be missed, but his memory lives on as he does in Heaven.

Comment: Actually, a better question is WILL THERE BE a cool down.

Not sure why there would be. Look at Vancouver: You import enough millionaires, and voila, you can no longer find a detached house in the city under a million dollars.

Why would that cool down? There are thousands upon thousands more, who have millions of dollars from overseas, in line competing with other buyers when properties pop up for sale.

Vancouver houses for many years have cost dozens of times the average annual local income, with no indication of letting up. It is a market fully detached from the interest rates in Canada and fully detached from the job market here. It has none of the attachments that led to previous cool-downs in Canadian cities, historically.
